newsitem.title: USA: Interscope record label president quits - sources.
newsitem.headline: Interscope record label president quits - sources.

text.p: The president of Interscope Records, the successful label that is 50 percent-owned by Seagram Co Ltd's Universal Music Group, has quit and is being wooed by Walt Disney Co's Hollywood Records label, industry sources said.

One source faimilar with the situation said Hollywood Records had approached Interscope president Tom Whalley a couple of months ago and that it was now taking another pass at the highly respected talent scout and executive who discovered such hit music acts as Tupac Shakur, the Wallflowers and Primus.
Another record company source said Whalley was on a short list of record industry executives in line to take over struggling Hollywood Records.
Officials at Interscope, Universal and Hollywood Records declined comment. Disney was unavailable for comment.
Whalley has been with red-hot Interscope since it was launched in 1990 and was promoted to the top spot last year.
At Hollywood Records, Whalley would fill the void created by the departure of label president Bob Pfeifer who recently exited after a three-year run to pursue other interests.
Interscope has been topping the charts with successful acts like the Wallflowers and Blackstreet and also distributes records for Death Row and Trauma Records.
